results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.

results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Witness
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Through intermingling static images of a playground, the beach and the town, David Greig paints a picture of Apollo Bay, on the west coast of Victoria, that is evocative and nostalgic.

results.title: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Neal Benezra, director of San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA), talks about the history of the institution with regards to its upcoming expansion. Benezra tells the story of his journey to find the architects who designed the expansion and explains the thinking behind the vision for the building.

This talk featured as part of the ‘William Kentridge: Five Themes’ exhibition public programs events. The exhibition was originally curated by SFMOMA in 2009 and has since travelled to New York, Paris, Vienna, Jerusalem and Moscow.

results.title: Fight for Country
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description: In 1998, over 5,000 people travelled to Kakadu, in the Northern Territory, to stand alongside the traditional owners of the land, the Mirrar people, and lend their support to the Jabiluka Campaign. The fight to prevent the development of the Jabiluka uranium mine was one of the biggest protest movements in Australia’s history and over 600 people were arrested in the process. It took film-maker Pip Starr four years to make this film, including one year spent documenting these historic events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions

results.title: Settlement Soccer Club
results.brief_description: Gene started a Friday afternoon soccer game at the Inverloch Community Hub, in south-eastern Victoria, and invited some young people from the Settlement communities to share in their love of the world game. ‘The Settlement Soccer Club’ is about connecting with others in the community and breaking down boundaries with the international language of the beautiful game. Anyone is welcome to play.

results.title: Swell Mamas
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Lucy and Geraldine have been the best of friends since school, when they both became mums they decided that their love of surfing and of being in the water would not take a back seat, so they started ‘Swell Mamas’. Dozens of mums across Inverloch in south-eastern Victoria, get together every Friday morning to connect, to laugh, to share and to feel the water wash over them.

results.title: The Ripple and the shed
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Inverloch’s Clock Tower Committee and Historical Society, in south-eastern Victoria, joined forces to create a maritime precinct along the town’s foreshore. The lovingly restored ‘Rocket Shed’ and newly built replica of ‘The Ripple’ sit side-by-side and showcase Inverloch’s connection to the water. ‘The Ripple’ is responsible for delivering timber for the first house built in Inverloch and the ‘Rocket Shed’ tells the story of a time when ocean rescues were less sophisticated than recent times.

results.title: The Bass Valley Community Centre
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Clare Le Serve started a craft group for young mums in the early 1980s, she could not have imagined that it would grow over the next 30 years to become such an amazing community asset. With the help of local volunteers and paid staff, the Community Centre offers essential services that make a positive impact on the people of Bass and the surrounding Waterline region in south-eastern Victoria.

results.title: The Corinella Jetty
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 2005, the small waterline community of Corinella in south eastern Victoria, was at risk of losing its iconic jetty. Barbara Oates, a local and owner of the general store, rallied the community to raise $10,000 to have the jetty renovated and extended, ensuring the prominent landmark would be enjoyed for generations to come.
